prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 in Q01322-0051
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Goal is to measure spatially resolved CO (3-2) map of a z~0.1 galaxy. Baseband 1 is set to measure the CO (3-2) spectral line and the remaining 3 basebands are intended to be continuum. The line flux surface density goal is estimated from IR luminosity, typical L(IR)/M_H2 and 3-2/1-0 ratios, and diameter known from H-alpha longslit spectroscopy. It represents a "typical" surface density assuming a 50% area filling factor over the diameter of the starforming disk, rather than a uniform average surface density.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
These 6 galaxies were selected from IRAS + SDSS to have L_IR > 1e11.5, large optical diameter, disky morphology, and star-forming spectrum. We obtained Herschel PACS spectra of the [C II], [O I], [O III], and [N II] far-IR lines. MMT long-slit optical spectra of H-alpha measure the star-forming diameter. In ALMA cycle 1 we were awarded time to observe the galaxies in CO 1-0, although the data have not been taken yet. The 6 galaxies span the range of L_IR and [C II]/FIR in our sample, from log [C II]/FIR = -3.6 to -2.5 (see Figure 2). A sample of 6 galaxies allows us to measure mean L_IR/M_H2 to 0.2 dex. Measuring CO J=3-2 will test whether CO excitation is correlated with SFR surface density, L_IR/M_H2, and/or [C II]/FIR.
The ratio of J=3-2 to 1-0 varies strongly for CO ladders in different types of galaxies; the 3-2 line is preferred because CO J=2-1 has less power to discriminate between warm and cold CO SLEDs, and J=2-1 is redshifted out of Band 6 for some of the sample. Higher J lines are more difficult due to the atmosphere and would require multiple pointings and ACA time due to the smaller primary beam.
We predicted S_CO (1-0) from L_IR, and L_IR/M_H2 ~ 100 Lsun/Msun (typical to high for disks), conservatively implying M_H2 ~ 6-10e9 Msun (e.g. Gracia-Carpio et al 2011), and M_H2 = 1e4 S_CO (D_L/1 Mpc)^2. The 6 galaxies have predicted observed flux S_CO (1-0) = 1.8 - 3.4 Jy km/s, median 2.4 Jy km/s. A typical to low excitation ratio is r_31 = T(3-2) / T(1-0) ~ 0.5 in antenna temperature, or 4.5 in flux units (e.g. Yao et al 2003, Papadopoulos et al 2011). This predicts a total flux in the J=3-2 line of median S_CO(3-2) = 10.8 Jy km/s.
The diameter of H-alpha in our MMT spectra is 6-13" and the emission peaks toward the center. The CO emission is likely centrally peaked and clumped rather than a uniform surface brightness. We assume an area filling factor of 50%, and a velocity spread of 30 km/s per beam . For a beam diameter 0.8", galaxy diameter in CO of 8", and 50% filling factor the emission is spread over 50 beams. For total flux 10.8 Jy km/s, the typical flux is 220 mJy km/s/beam. For a 5 sigma detection in each beam we need to reach rms of 44 mJy km/s, or equivalent flux 1.45 mJy integrated over the 30 km/s velocity width. We use this rms = 1.45 mJy in the OT. The significance of total detection and of measuring excitation as a function of radius is well above 5 sigma since we can average in annuli.
The ALMA OT estimates that for typical rms = 1.45 mJy in bandwidth 30 km/s, the galaxies need 5-7 minutes on-source and 30-37 minutes total. For three of the brighter, larger angular diameter sources, the CO emission may be ~10-12" in diameter and we have requested ACA observations, which require no more 12-m time but ~2.5 hours ACA time.
The continuum sensitivity, combining the basebands, is on average ??? muJy/beam. For a typical galaxy with S_100 um = 1.5 Jy, and a Draine \& Li (2007) dust model, the expected total continuum flux at 0.9mm is 10 mJy, yielding a strong detection of the total flux and a spatially resolved radial profile with averaging in annuli. These can be used with the IR fluxes to constrain the cool dust in dust mass modeling.

Baseband 1 is set to measure the CO (3-2) spectral line and the remaining 3 basebands are intended to be continuum. prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Please see technical justification for science goal #1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(3-2) observations of 6 z ~ 0.1 IR-luminous galaxies that are large disks, unlike most low-z LIRG/ULIRGs which are centrally concentrated mergers. These are 6 galaxies for which we are measuring CO(1-0) in Cycle 1, from a sample of 16 that we observed in [C II] 158 microns and other far-IR lines with Herschel. At high-z, many star-forming galaxies are disky with high gas fraction, with star formation spread over a large area. Our sample are analogs for these high-z disky galaxies, yet can be studied in more detail. [C II] 158 um is a major cooling line in star-forming clouds and the far-IR lines probe the density and UV ionization. CO(3-2) maps probe higher density gas than CO(1-0), and measure the spatial variation of the CO line excitation ratio, sensitive to temperature and gas density. We will test the excitation dependence on radius, local gas and SFR surface density, SF efficiency L_IR / M_H_2, T_dust, and galaxy type (luminous disks vs. samples of mergers). We will test models in which the CO excitation is set by SFR surface density, and calibrate the CO 3-2/1-0 ratio for interpreting high-J CO fluxes of high-z galaxies and down-converting them to CO 1-0.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00539.S - Molecular gas and starforming regions in disky U/LIRGs - analogs for high-z starforming galaxies - PI Benjamin Weiner
